titles.title: Expressing the sense of the House of Representatives that a United Nations Emergency Peace Service capable of intervening in the early stages of a humanitarian crisis could save millions of lives, billions of dollars, and is in the interests of the United States.

action.text: Referred to the House Committee on International Relations.

bill.summary: 3/17/2005--Introduced. Expresses the sense of the House of Representatives that the United States should use its voice and vote at the United Nations (UN) to support the creation of a permanent United Nations Emergency Peace Service which should: (1) be able to act immediately in an emerging humanitarian crisis; and (2) be recruited from member nations with a single command structure able to provide an integrated service encompassing 10,000 to 15,000 civilian, police, judicial, military, and relief professionals.
